PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE & SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: CBA earnings and reaction to Australian budget
content:
AUSTRALIA

Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA AT)
- Co. reports Q3 cash profit AUD 2.35bln, notes slight decline in group net interest margin. (Newswires)
- Co. says underlying operating expenses are higher due to provisions.
- Co. reached in-principle settlement with ASIC regarding BBSW proceedings and will pay a AUD 5mln fine.
- Co. is mulling full sale of Colonial First State instead of just the asset management business. (The Australian)

CSR (CSR AT)
- Co. FY18 Adj. net AUD 212.7mln vs. Exp. AUD 214.4mln. (Newswires)

Incitec Pivot (IPL AT)
- Co. H1 adj. net AUD 147.1mln vs. Prev. AUD 152.1mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 1.68bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.54bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT)
- Co. in discussions regarding sale of Ascalon Capital to Generation Development Group. (AFR)

WorleyParsons (WOR AT)
- Co. reports Q3 backlog of AUD 6.0bln. (Newswires)

Other News
- Australia federal budget 2018/19 contained tax reductions that will cost AUD 140bln over 10 years, while it sees budget surplus a year sooner than prev. forecast. Furthermore, the budget sees 2018/19 budget deficit at AUD 14.5bln vs AUD 20.5bln forecast in December. Furthermore, GDP growth forecasts were maintained at 3% through to 2021/22, while CPI estimates were maintained at 2.25% in 2018/19 and kept at 2.5% thereafter. (Newswires)
- S&P stated that risks to Australia’s fiscal outlook remains negative. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Asahi Glass (5201 JT)
- Co. Q1 net JPY 24.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 19.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

GS Yuasa (6674 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net fell 6.4% Y/Y to JPY 11.5bln, Co. announces 1-for-5 share consolidation. (Newswires)

Isuzu Motors (7202 JT)
- Co. expected to report FY 19 oper. profit rose by 5% Y/Y to around JPY 172bln which would miss analysts forecasts by around JPY 10bln. (Newswires)

Minebea (6479 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 59.4bln vs. Prev. JPY 41.1bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Mizuho Financial Group (8411 JT)
- Mizuho Bank is said to be considering investment in Chinese brokerages as China eases restrictions. (Nikkei)

Nomura Holdings (8604 JT)
- China securities regulator is said to be examining Co. application for a JV brokerage in China. (Newswires)

Screen Holdings (7735 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 28.5bln vs. Prev. JPY 24.2bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Sumitomo Heavy (6302 JT)
- Co. FY17/18 net JPY 34.7bln vs. Prev. JPY 33.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

KCC Corp (002380 KS)
- Co. Q1 net KRW 376.1bln vs. Exp. KRW 194.0bln, rev. KRW 916.6bln vs. Exp. KRW 966.4bln. (Newswires)

LG Display (034220 KS)
- Co. dismissed reports that it received KRW 1tln direct investment from Alphabet (GOOG). (Newswires)

Samsung Securities (016360 KS)
- South Korea FSS to take legal action against firm for failing to operate with due internal standards for safe electronic transactions following the mistaken share bonus payout. (Newswires)

Other News
- US Secretary of State Pompeo is travelling to North Korea to prepare for planned US-North Korea summit, while there were also separate reports that US President Trump stated that the date and location for US summit with North Korea have been chosen. (Yonhap/Newswires)
- US President Trump and Chinese President Xi agreed on a phone call that sanctions on North Korea will remain in place until it permanently dismantles nuclear programmes, according to the White House. (Newswires)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
IRAN NUCLEAR AGREEMENT

US President Trump announced the US is to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal and that the US will institute 'highest level' of sanctions on Iran. US President Trump also stated that the deal should never have been made and has allowed Iran to continue to enrich uranium, while he stated to be ready, willing and able to renegotiate a deal with Iran. (Newswires)

US Treasury Department said oil related sanctions on Iran are to be re-imposed in 180 days and US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that effectively sanctions will be going into place immediately. Furthermore, Mnuchin also commented that the US will be working with allies on a comprehensive deal and that firms can seek waivers or special licences to operate in Iran. (Newswires)

French President Macron noted that France will work collectively on a broader framework, covering nuclear activity, the post-2025 period, ballistic activity, and stability in the Middle-East, notably Syria, Yemen, and Iraq. Furthermore, there were also comments by EU’s Mogherimi that the EU vows to uphold Iran nuclear accord despite Trump’s decision. (Twitter/Newswires)

Iran's leader Rouhani said Iran is committed to its own and confirmed that Iran will continue the nuclear deal with members of the P5+1 even without US. (State TV)

There was volatility in crude prices with the rumour mill rife in the hours leading to the announcement, in which crude initially fell around USD 2 to below USD 68/bbl amid CNN reports that US President Trump is to announce new sanctions against Iran and will not withdraw from the deal. However, the weakness was then pared on conflicting reports that President Trump decided to pull-out of the agreement which was later confirmed and underpinned WTI crude back above USD 70/bbl. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said US is willing to work with China, strengthen cooperation and properly deal with trade problems. (Newswires)

Australia sees 2018/19 budget deficit at AUD 14.5bln vs AUD 20.5bln seen in December, sees GDP growth at 3% in 2018/19 and staying there through 2021/22. sees inflation at 2.25% in 2018/19 and 2.5% thereafter. (Newswires)


UK

UK Government’s plan to leave EU single market was defeated in the upper house of parliament in which they voted to participate in or have formal relationships with EU agencies after leaving EU. (Newswires)

UK PM May spokesman said the UK will be leaving the customs union when Brexit transition period ends in Dec. 2020, while the spokesman added officials asked to keep working on customs proposals as a priority, but confident an agreement can be reached. (Newswires)

Eurosceptic ministers are reported to be worried that UK PM May could bypass her Brexit war cabinet and ask the full cabinet for support regarding a customs partnership with the EU. (Telegraph)


EU

ECB's Vasiliauskas said ending QE in December is a realistic scenario and there is no reason to dramaticize the recent economic slowdown. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

US API weekly Crude Stocks (4 May) -1.850M vs. Exp. -0.700M (Prev. +3.427M). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia Energy Ministry said they will coordinate efforts with Opec+ to mitigate the impact of any potential oil supply shortfall on market stability. (Newswires)

EIA cut forecast for 2018 world oil demand growth by 30k bpd and now sees 1.76mln bpd increase, while it raised 2018 US crude output estimate to 10.72mln bpd from 10.69mln bpd. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICAL

US President Trump and China's Xi agreed on a phone call that sanctions on North Korea will remain in place until it permanently dismantles nuclear programmes, according to the White House. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures started off on the backfoot as markets awaited Trump’s decision on the nuclear deal, but mixed source reports resulted in choppy trade until it was confirmed Trump is to pull out of the deal, resulting in a slightly risk off tone. However, this changed heading into the close where some of the earlier losses were pared back.  Sector specifics, utilities underperformed following a poor earnings report from Aes (AES) who reported a softer than expected revenue. Telecoms also underperformed in Tuesday trade following earnings from Dish (DISH) where revenue fell short, and the co. saw a net decline of roughly 94,000 Pay TV customers, and its average monthly subscriber rate for Dish TV was at 1.47%, lower than the 1.92% for Q1 of 2017. M&A news today returned to Shire (SHPG) and Takeda (4502 JT) as Shire agreed to be purchased for GBP 46bln (USD 62.4bln), putting an end to the takeover battle between the two. Focus also lied on Comcast (CMCSA) who are said to be arranging an all cash offer for 21st Century Fox’s (FOXA) assets for USD 60bln. SPX -0.03% at 2671, NDX -0.09% at 6815, DJI +0.01% at 24360.

Treasuries were lower on Tuesday with most of the action concentrated in the front end and belly of the curve. The 5yr yield was up by c.3bps, the 2yr and 10yr yields were higher by c.2bps. The Treasury auctioned USD 31bln in 3yr notes with a tail of 0.1bps. The yield came in at 2.664%, the highest since May 2007. Dealers were left with the largest proportion of the issuance at 42.2%, well above the 6-auction average. Directs were awarded 12.3% and indirect 14.6%, the smallest portion since July 2016. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 5+ ticks lower at 119-16+.

US MARKET WRAP 8 May 2018: Crude on back foot but off lows as US pulls out of Iran nuclear deal
content:
• * SNAP-SHOT: Equities flat, Treasuries lower, DXY higher, Crude volatile.
  • * REAR-VIEW: Trumps pulls out from Iran nuclear deal
  • * AHEAD: US PPI, Fed’s Bostic to speak, earnings from UCG IM, DTE GY, FOXA, BKNG.

* GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump confirmed the US is to pull out of the Iran nuclear deal with the 'highest level' of sanctions to be imposed on Iran. After criticising the deal, noting it should never have been made, Trump said to be ready, willing and able to renegotiate an agreement with Iran. In response, France, Germany and the UK released a joint statement saying they regret the US decision. The first response from Iran came from the country’s leader Rouhani who argued Iran is committed to its own obligations whilst the US is not. Rouhani added that from now on, the Iran deal is between Iran and five countries, namely UK, Germany, France, Russia and China, and he is ready to resume its nuclear work following talks with EU members of the deal.

*FED SPEAK: Fed’s Chair Powell noted the market is "reasonably well aligned" with the Fed dot plot, adds markets should not be surprised with the Fed's actions.

*ECB SPEAK: ECB’s Vasiliauskas said ending QE in December is a realistic scenario and there is no reason to dramatise the recent economic slowdown.

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.03% at 2671, NDX -0.09% at 6815, DJI +0.01% at 24360.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: -0.46%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.46%, Energy: +0.78%, Financials: +0.69%, Health Care: -0.78%, Industrials: +0.72%, Materials: -0.26%, Technology: +0.29%, Telecoms: -1.29%, Utilities: -2.52%.

US Equity futures started off on the backfoot as markets awaited Trump’s decision on the nuclear deal, but mixed source reports resulted in choppy trade until it was confirmed Trump is to pull out of the deal, resulting in a slightly risk off tone. However, this changed heading into the close where some of the earlier losses were pared back.  Sector specifics, utilities underperformed following a poor earnings report from Aes (AES) who reported a softer than expected revenue. Telecoms also underperformed in Tuesday trade following earnings from Dish (DISH) where revenue fell short, and the co. saw a net decline of roughly 94,000 Pay TV customers, and its average monthly subscriber rate for Dish TV was at 1.47%, lower than the 1.92% for Q1 of 2017. M&A news today returned to Shire (SHPG) and Takeda (4502 JT) as Shire agreed to be purchased for GBP 46bln (USD 62.4bln), putting an end to the takeover battle between the two. Focus also lied on Comcast (CMCSA) who are said to be arranging an all cash offer for 21st Century Fox’s (FOXA) assets for USD 60bln.

* CRUDE: WTI crude futures settle lower by USD 1.67 at USD 69.06; Brent Crude futures settle lower by USD 1.32 at USD 74.85.

Crude prices pared back losses after Trump announced the US is pulling out of the nuclear deal, with new sanctions to be imposed on Iran in 180 days, however, the major benchmarks still settled lower. Oil traded choppy ahead of the announcement, as media reports kept refuting each other on whether the US would leave the deal or not.  Despite the boost in later trade, prices were down for the day. 

Goldman Sachs noted beforehand that if US were to pull out of the Iran deal and secondary sanctions are reintroduced, there may not be an immediate impact on the oil market and potentially not as large as the 1mln bpd loss of exports in the period of 2012-2015.

* TREASURIES: US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 5+ ticks lower at 119-16+.

Treasuries were lower on Tuesday with most of the action concentrated in the front end and belly of the curve. The 5yr yield was up by c.3bps, the 2yr and 10yr yields were higher by c.2bps. The Treasury auctioned USD 31bln in 3yr notes with a tail of 0.1bps. The yield came in at 2.664%, the highest since May 2007. Dealers were left with the largest proportion of the issuance at 42.2%, well above the 6-auction average. Directs were awarded 12.3% and indirect 14.6%, the smallest portion since July 2016. 

*FOREX: *DXY: The index has now advanced past the 93.000 marker to a new high for the year to date around 93.280 amidst broad USD gains, and with the next bullish objective near 93.500 (a key Fib at 93.522 to be precise).

*CHF, JPY: As noted, relatively contained losses vs the USD with 1.0000-50 and 108.85-109.30 respective ranges, while both currencies sharply outperformed an increasingly weak EUR as the crosses recoiled to sub-1.1900 and 130.00.

*GBP: The Pound derived a degree of underlying support from M&A flows as Shire finally warmed to Takeda’s takeover terms, with GBPJPY briefly over 148.00 and Cable close to 1.3600 when news of a deal broke, but the former currently around 147.50 and latter nearer 1.3550, though EURGBP remains under 0.8800 on the aforementioned more pronounced single currency selling.

*EUR, CAD: Both around 0.65% adrift vs the USD, with EURUSD down to fresh 2018 lows under 1.1850 having breached a key Fib (1.1876), but then rebounded above that level finding support around the 1.1860 area. USDCAD hit new multi-week highs above 1.2950 to reach 1.2985 amidst more NAFTA talk highlighting progress, but little sign of a deal, and following weaker than forecast Canadian housing starts data. Next resistance on the radar end of Q1 peaks circa 1.3000.

*AUD, NZD:  Ending Tuesday’s session as the biggest G10 decliners vs the USD amidst broad falls in commodity prices (which also weighed on the Loonie of course), and with the AUD also a victim of data disappointment (retail sales missed consensus) and some fiscal angst surrounding the annual budget (as tax cuts and infrastructure spending could hamper predictions for an earlier surplus than previously expected if based on too optimistic basic material and other forecasts). AUDUSD has lost more ground below 0.7500 and filled bids at 0.7470 on the way down to a 0.7435 low, while the Kiwi is only just holding above 0.6950.

content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 31bln 3-year notes

The US Treasury increased the auction sizes at the quarterly refunding announcement and will auction USD 73bln in 3-year notes (USD 31bln, today), 10-year notes (USD 25bln, Wednesday) and 30-year bonds (USD 17bln, Thursday) this week. With a total of USD 39.1bln maturing on 15th May, the auction will raise USD 33.9bln in the week. The bidding deadline for the auction is 1800BST (1300 eastern time) with results expected shortly after.

Last month’s 3-year note auction was not received particularly well; the auction was covered just 2.85x, below the 6-auction average of 2.97x and the auctioned tailed by 0.1 basis point. Dealers were also left with a higher than average proportion of the issuance at 40.8%.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Buy, Buy Dollar, and bye-bye Iran nuclear deal?
content:
DXY

The index has now advanced past the 93.000 marker to a new high for the year to date around 93.280 amidst broad Usd gains, and with the next bullish objective near 93.500 (a key Fib at 93.522 to be precise). No sign of any apprehension or much reluctance to keeping buying the Greenback ahead of US President Trump’s decision whether to pull out of the Iran nuclear accord or not, although the traditional safe-haven currencies did buck the overall underperforming trend for a while before yielding to the almost insatiable Dollar bid.

content: Bunds and Gilts have succumbed to more selling pressure and extended losses in the process to ¼ point and 32 ticks respectively at new Eurex and Liffe lows of 159.06 and 122.24. To recap, 159.07-02 forms technical support for Bunds and incorporates Monday’s intraday low and a rising trend-line, while resistance resides at 159.31. For Gilts there is little on the charts before 121.70 (apart from 122.00 of course) and the contract peak up at 123.03. Meanwhile in the currency markets, the Usd/DXY is carving out loftier peaks and gains vs peers in stages rather than unison as the Jpy and Chf continue to buck the general trend (safe-haven status impacting ahead of Trump’s final verdict on the current Iran nuclear agreement). The index has now been as high as 93.140 and inching closer to some major upside chart levels in the 93.500 area

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 8th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • WTI crude futures continue to retrace from three-and-a-half year highs
  • Dollar index firming up again after another bout of consolidation, with the Dollar bid against all major counterparts bar the Jpy and Chf.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include APIs, President Trump (Iranian announcement at 1400ET/1900BST) and a 3yr note auction

 

ASIA-PAC

Asia equity markets traded mostly positive following a similar performance on Wall St where all 3 majors closed in the green but off best levels after a late retreat in crude, while mixed Chinese trade data and a looming Trump announcement on the Iran agreement has also kept upside in the region contained. ASX 200 (+0.1%) is positive with gains led by strength in the largest weighted financials sector. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) shrugged off a firmer currency and conformed to the overall risk appetite, while Hang Seng (+1.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) outperformed with healthcare and financials front running the gains despite further liquidity inaction and another consecutive net neutral position by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre as focus centred on riskier assets, while the 10yr JGB auction also failed to impact prices with the results somewhat inconclusive in which the b/c printed higher than previous and accepted prices declined.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3674 (Prev. 6.3584)

Chinese Exports (USD)(Apr) Y/Y 12.9% vs. Exp. 8.0% (Prev. -2.7%)

Chinese Imports (USD)(Apr) Y/Y 21.5% vs. Exp. 16.0% (Prev. 14.4%)

Australia sees 2018/19 budget deficit at AUD 14.5bln vs AUD 20.5bln seen in December, sees GDP growth at 3% in 2018/19 and staying there through 2021/22. sees inflation at 2.25% in 2018/19 and 2.5% thereafter. (Newswires)

Australian Retail Sales (Mar) M/M 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)

Australian Retail Sales (Q1) Q/Q 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.9%)

New Zealand Inflation Expectations (Q2) Q/Q 2.0% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump is to announce decision on the Iran nuclear deal today at 1400ET/1900BST. This comes despite reports yesterday that UK, France and Germany are close to a package deal to attempt to persuade US President Trump not to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal, according to a senior diplomat. US President Trump is said to be leaning towards dropping the Iran agreement and re-imposing sanctions according to diplomats familiar with discussions, although reports added it is unclear if he would moderate a move to scrap the Iran nuclear deal by permitting EU countries to proceed with economic ties with Iran without being penalized by US. (Newswires/NYT)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed Chair Powell (neutral) says the market is "reasonably well aligned" with the Fed dot plot, adds markets should not be surprised with the Fed's actions. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (non-voter, neutral) said the base case remains at 3 hikes total for this year. (Newswires)

Riksbank minutes: Several members expressed concerns about development of inflation going forward, as well as pointing out that it is important the Krona exchange rate develops in a manner compatible with inflation stabilizing close to the target. Riksbank’s Skingsley added that he is likely to back a hike in either October or December, and that as the Krona is expected to strengthen again over the forecast period, the effects of inflation can be seen as moderate. (Newswires)

Riksbank's Jansson says inflation does not have to be exactly 2%, but near it, so a confidence problem doesn't happen, and that the SEK is clearly weaker than they expected, and that inflation needs continued support by monetary policy. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Senior White House official stated that President Trump will request USD 15bln in spending reductions from Congress which will be focused on money not being utilized.  Furthermore, the official stated that cuts will include USD 7bln from the Children's health insurance program and that another large rescission package will be proposed later in the year. (Newswires)

UK PM May is reportedly facing renewed turmoil regarding Brexit options and is said to be under pressure from MPs across different parties to accept EEA membership or risk defeat in Commons. (Guardian) Furthermore, Dozens of Eurosceptic MPs in the UK's Conservative party are expected to express their frustration today regarding a lack of direction for the UK's future post-Brexit. (Telegraph)

EQUITIES

Stoxx 600 is down 0.5% amid broad risk aversion ahead of the US decision on the Iranian nuclear deal later in the day. The FTSE (+0.1%) currently outperforming as UK traders return to their desks post-bank holiday, as well as being given a boost by Takeda’s GBP 46bln approach for Shire (+4.1%). FTSEMIB (-2.2%) is the worst performer due to election concerns, with the DAX (-0.4%) also underperforming, following an earnings miss for Deutsche Post (-6.1%).

FX

CAD

A relatively sharp pull-back in crude prices amidst speculation that the UK, France and Germany are on the cusp of a plan that might tempt US President Trump not to abandon the Iranian nuclear treaty, plus ongoing NAFTA uncertainty as negotiations resume are weighing heavily on the Loonie, as Usd/Cad spikes through the top of recent ranges and more convincingly above 1.2900. In fact, the pair is testing the water above 1.2950 at fresh multi-week peaks, with early March highs around 1.3000 next on the upside.

SEK

Extending gains vs the Eur (to sub-10.5000 levels) and Nok (also undermined by the retreat in oil) in wake of Riksbank minutes reaffirming year end rate hike guidance and the broad Swedish Central Bank view that the Krona will rally over time after a temporary period of weakness.

DXY

Firming up again after another bout of consolidation, with the Dollar bid against all major counterparts bar the Jpy and Chf. The index has now printed above 93.000 vs 92.974 at best yesterday, with little reaction to latest comments from Fed Chair Powell who merely stressed the need for clear policy communication to avoid market turbulence, He also claimed that EMs can cope with US normalisation, but the Try for one continues to struggle at new record lows vs the Greenback circa 4.3000.

JPY/CHF

Both showing relative resilience vs the Usd around 109.00 and within a 1.0000-50 band respectively, with perhaps some underlying safe-haven demand evident ahead of Trump’s eagerly-awaited Iran deal or no deal announcement (14.00ET/19.00BST).

NZD/EUR

Both mildly softer vs the Usd below big figures (0.7000 and 1.1900), with the Kiwi slightly depressed by softer NZ inflation expectations and the single currency still succumbing to weaker Eurozone data and position paring from a record long base. Eur/Usd has breached its 250 WMA around 1.1896, while on the upside decent option expiries (1.5 bn) at 1.1950 are keeping a lid on prices.

GBP

Volatile as UK participants return from May Day to confirmation of a mega M&A deal that lifted Cable towards 1.3600 at one stage, and Gbp/Jpy up through 148.00, but the Pound now beating a retreat to retest 1.3500 vs the Usd and back below its 200 DMA (1.3542).

AUD

Another laggard on broadly weaker commodity prices and softer than forecast Aussie retail sales data overnight, with Aud/Usd back under the 0.7500 mark and Aud/Nzd losing 1.0700+ status again.

FIXED INCOME

Gilts got a brief extra lift from much a weaker than expected Halifax hpi to marginally extend their Liffe peak to 122.69 (+13 ticks), but have been dragged back since with core bond peers (to a new low foe the session at 122.43) as Bunds probed below the first technical support area (159.20-18) to 159.10 (-21 ticks). 159.07-02 is the next downside chart objective, though the 10 year German benchmark has bounced more recently as the political pressure mounts on Italian BTPs to more than a full point at 138.06 vs Monday’s 139.38 close. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are straddling yesterday’s settlement levels amidst a mildly flatter curve bias ahead of the 1st leg of this week’s quarterly refunding - $31 bn 3 year notes.

COMMODITIES

Commodities are mixed as WTI crude futures continue to retrace from three-and-a-half year highs, back below the USD 70.00/bbl level following reports that European powers are close to a package deal to try and persuade Trump not to withdraw from the Iran deal. That said, later reports suggest that Trump may be inclined to dropping out of the agreement when he announces his decision at 1900BST today, a move that can disrupt global oil supply. “Iran’s exports could be cut by 200K bpd to 300K bpd” says RBC if the US restores sanctions.

Elsewhere, gold prices have been choppy, tracking fluctuations in the USD, while 3-month copper on the LME was up 0.3% and zinc climbed 1.5% on expectations for strong Chinese data in the coming weeks.

Iran has set June's light crude official price for Asia USD 2/bbl above Oman/Dubai quotes. (Newswires)

FTSEMIB (-1.6%) is the worst performer due to election concerns, with the DAX (-0.38%) also underperforming, following an earnings miss for Deutsche Post (-7.1%).

CAD

The index has now printed above 93.000 vs 92.974 at best yesterday, with little reaction to latest comments from Fed Chair Powell who merely stressed the need for clear policy communication to avoid market turbulence, He also claimed that EMs can cope with US normalisation, but the Try for one continues to struggle at new record lows vs the Greenback circa 4.3000.

content: A rather inauspicious return to Liffe, as expected, given little major or clear moves in external counterparts on May Day in the UK. However, Gilts have recovered from an initial and early dip to 122.48 vs last Friday’s 122.56 close to trade up at 122.62 before fading, while the Short Sterling strip has been narrowly mixed around parity in the run up to the latest Halifax update on UK prices. Bunds: losing more momentum off Mondays session high
content: Several bearish factors could be listed as the 10 year German benchmark retreats a bit further from yesterday’s intraday peak, with the early data exceeding market expectations and comments from ECB’s Smets suggesting that the next phase of the QE exit strategy may be discussed this summer. However, this is not new guidance given that most expect the ECB to provide details of the wind down from Eur30 bn monthly purchases that runs until the end of September by mid-2018. Moreover, for Bunds in particular the ECB has stated that more German debt will be bought in the short term to balance sub-quota PSPP activity recently, so the pull-back in early Eurex trade is more consolidative within a 159.18-28 range vs Monday’s 159.31 close. Ahead, Dutch, Austrian and German linker supply.

DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

**OF NOTE, UK AND IRISH STORIES ARE BEING BROUGHT FORWARD FROM YESTERDAY DUE TO MONDAY BEING A BANK HOLIDAY**

8th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded mostly positive following a similar performance on Wall St where all 3 majors closed in the green but off best levels after a late retreat in crude, while mixed Chinese trade data and a looming Trump announcement on the Iran agreement has also kept upside in the region contained. ASX 200 (+0.2%) is positive with gains led by strength in the largest weighted financials sector and amid some optimism ahead of the federal budget announcement which is expected to include tax cuts for low and middle-income earners, as well as billions for infrastructure spending. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) shrugged off a firmer currency and conformed to the overall risk appetite, while Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) outperformed with healthcare and financials front running the gains despite further liquidity inaction and another consecutive net neutral position by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre as focus centred on riskier assets, while the 10yr JGB auction also failed to impact prices with the results somewhat inconclusive in which the b/c printed higher than previous and accepted prices declined.

FTSE

BP (BP/ LN) – The co. signed the Kirkuk oilfield development contract with Iraq at a ceremony in Basra, according to oil officials. (Newswires)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – Pact to sell 14.16% stake in Rosneft will not proceed, and the stake is to be transfer to a wholly owned unit of QIA. (Newswires)

Barclays (BARC LN) – The co. has become involved in another mis-selling scandal in relation to loans for solar panels. (Times)

ITV (ITV LN) – The co is in talks with BBC and Channel 4 in to create UK streaming service to combat Netflix (NFLX) and Amazon (AMZN). (Newswires)

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Suppliers to Sainsbury’s and Asda may see up to 2500 jobs at risk if the proposed merger goes ahead. (Times)

Sky (SKY LN) -  Comcast (CMCSA) signed a formal notification to the European Commission over its intention to buy the co. (Newswires)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – The co. has agreed a pension deal with unions that keeps the final salary scheme open to members until 2024, and will save USD 196mln over the next 3 years. (Times)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – Co. and Liberty Global (LBTYA) are in talks about a takeover of cable networks in Germany, Czech Republic, Hungary and Romania. The deal is estimated to be worth EUR 21bln and are in final stages. It is understood that Vodafone plans to brush aside concerns that its struggling Indian operation could be an obstacle. (The Telegraph)

SSE (SSE LN) – UK’s CMA could unveil this week whether or not it will probs the Co.’s merger with Npower. (FT)

Imperial Brands (IMB LN) – Co. could be considering strategic options such as the sale of some or all of its business amid investor pressure. (Times)

Shire (SHP LN) - Takeda (4502 JT) are approaching a deal to purchase Shire (SHP LN) in a USD 64bln deal, according to sources. (Newswires)

Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA LN) – A unit of the Co., Shell Gas BV, is to sell its entire stake in Canadian Natural Resources (CNQ) for USD 3.3bln, which will be used to reduce debt. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

First Group (FGP LN) – Investors in the Co. are reportedly looking for Apollo Global Management to make another offer for the Co. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Deutsche Telekom (DTE GY) – US senators and lawmakers have expressed “serious concerns” over T-mobile’s (TMUS) plans to buy Sprint (S). (Newswires)

Deutsche Post (DPW GY) – Q1 EBIT EUR 905mln vs. Exp. EUR 972mln, net EUR 600mln vs. prev. EUR 633mln and revenue EUR 14.8bln vs. Prev. EUR 14.9bln. (Newswires)

E.ON (EOAN GY) – Q1 adj. EBIT +24% at EUR 1.3bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.2bln. Q1 adj. net profit +38% at EUR 727mln vs. Exp. EUR 687mln. Co. still expects adj. EBIT of EUR 2.8bln- EUR 3bln vs. Exp EUR 2.9bln. Co. still expects adj. net income of EUR 1.3bln-EUR 1.5bln in 2018 vs. Exp. EUR 1.4bln. (Newswires)

Munich Re (MUV2 GY) – Operating profit EUR 1.28bln vs. Exp. EUR 1.01bln, gross written premium EUR 13.1bln vs. Exp. EUR 13.2bln; maintains 2018 profit guidance. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Evonik (EVK GY) – Q1 sales +1% to EUR 3.68bln, EBITDA +14% to EUR 679mln, net income +97% to EUR 291mln. The co. confirms 2018 EBITDA adj. EBITDA expected to increase to between EUR 2.4bln and EUR 2.6bln. (Newswires)

Hochtief (HOT GY) – Q1 sales up 2.3% at EUR 5.266bln. Net profit up 13.9% at EUR 106mln. Confirms 2018 guidance for operational net profit of EUR 470-520mln. (Newswires)

Lufthansa (LHA GY) – The co. has said to purchase 16 plane with a list price of approx. EUR 2.1bln. To order 12 A320-Family aircrafts and 6 A320NEOS into firm orders for 2022. Sees no impact on this year’s investment plans amid its delivery of Boeing (BA) and Airbus (AIR FP). (Newswires)

Schaeffler (SHA GY) – Co. is to announce new leadership structure on July 1st and will cut 950 jobs. (Newswires)

Uniper (UN01 GY) – Q1 Adj. EBIT at EUR 350mln vs. Exp. EUR 366mln, revenue EUR 21.0bln vs. Exp EUR 22.3bln. Dividend forecast confirmed to 2020, EBIT affirmed at EUR 0.8-1.1bln. (Newswires) 

Symrise (SY1 GY) – Q1 sales +1.5% to EUR 776.9mln vs. Exp EUR 772mln, organic growth of 7.5% in Q1, affirms FY objectives. (Newswires)

Leg Immobilien (LEG GY) – Q1 in-place rent per square metre +3.4% LFL. Q1 FFO I EUR 74.2mln. 2018. CO sees 2018 dividend at 70% of FFO I. Co. sees 2018 FFO I in the range if EUR 315mln to EUR 323mln. (Newswires)

Scout24 (G24 GY) – Q1 net profit EUR 30.2mln vs. Prev. EUR 24.2mln. Q1 revenue +10.3% to EUR 123.4mln. Co. is well on track to achieve FY 2018 targets. (Newswires)

Axel Springer (SPR GY) – Q1 revenue EUR 773.5mln vs. Exp. EUR 797.3mln, net EUR 80.9mln vs. Prev. EUR 78.1mln and adj. EBITDA EUR 171.2mln vs. Prev. EUR 147.2mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

CAC

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Lagardere (MMB FP) – The co. stated its share repurchase programmes could be carried out at a max price of EUR 40/shr. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Vivendi (VIV FP), the largest shareholder in Telecom Italia, reaffirmed its long-term commitment to the company and said is pleased Amos Genish has been appointed CEO. (Newswires)

UniCredit (UCG IM) -  Hedge fund Caius Capital has accused the Co. of misclassifying certain capital. (FT)

Salvatore Ferragamo (SFER IM) – Q1 net EUR 9mln vs. Exp. EUR 10mln. Revenue EUR 304mln vs. Exp. EUR 304mln. (Newswires)

Postnl (PNL NA) – Q1 revenue at EUR 875mln vs. prev. EUR 870mln, underlying cash operating income EUR 29mln vs. prev. EUR 50mln, profit for period at EUR 14mln vs. prev. EUR 41mln. FY outlook confirmed. (Newswires)

DSM (DSM NA) – Q1 total adjusted EBITDA +56% and net profit +122% to EUR 331mln. Q1 sales EUR 2.24bln vs. Prev. EUR 2.16bln. End of Q1 cash from operating activities +58% to EUR 310mln. Co. confirms its increased FY outlook 2018. (Newswires)

Iberdrola (IBE SM) – Co. are to offload their UK gas plants for EUR 2bln. (Newswires)

Endesa (ELE SM) – Q1 net profit EUR 372mln vs. Prev. EUR 253mln. Q1 EBITDA EUR 880mln vs. Prev. EUR 702mln. Q1 revenue EUR 5.17bln vs. Prev. EUR 5.22bln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

Lundbeck (LUN DC) – Q1 revenue of DKK 4.59bln vs. Exp. DKK 4.35bln, EBIT of DKK 1.66bln vs. prrev. DKK 1.01bln FY guidance unchanged. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

Swiss Life (SLHN SW) – Q1 fee income of CHF 395mln, up 9%; group wide premiums came to CHF 7.0bln, so. Says they are confident they will achieve targets for 2018. (Newswires)

Dufry (DUFN SW) – Q1 net profit CHF -45mln vs. Exp. CHF -39mln. EBITDA CHF 183mln vs. Exp. CHF 172mln. Revenue CHF 1.82bln vs. Exp. CHF 1.81bln. (Newswires)

Adecco (ADEN SW) – Q1 net income EUR 130mln vs. Exp. EUR 149mln. Q1 revenue EUR 5.69bln vs. Exp. EUR 5.69bln. Q1 EBIT EUR 194mln vs. Exp. EUR 225mln. (Newswires)

PSP Swiss Rpoperty (PSPN SW)  - Q1 net income of CHF 40.3mln vs prev. CHF 39.7mln, rental income of CHF 69.1mln vs. prev. CHF 68.4mln, an EBITDA for FY of over CHF 235mln is still expected. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

US

US Equity futures traded with little action before the Wall St open where the thee major indices spiked higher supported by outperformance in the energy sector, amid higher oil prices, with Exxon Mobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP) which sent the S&P 500 in close proximity to the 50DMA at 2679. News that European powers were close to a package deal to try and persuade Trump not to withdraw from the Iran deal then saw energy move lower and stocks in the energy sector pared gains. Tech names also printed a second consecutive day of gains supported by Apple (APPL) which hit a record high for the second straight session, boosted by Warren Buffett increasing its stake to USD 4.7bln followed by positive comments on the stock

INDICES: SPX +0.35% at 2672, NDX +0.79% at 6822 , DJI +0.40% at 24359 

SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals: %, Cons Non-Cyclicals: -0.89%, Energy: +0.18%, Financials: +0.53%, Health Care: -0.06%, Industrials: +0.56%, Materials: +0.13%, Technology: +0.76%, Telecoms: -0.69%, Utilities: -0.57%.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asia equity markets traded mostly positive but off best levels amid crude retreat, Chinese trade and looming Trump announcement on Iran
content:
• Asia equity markets traded mostly positive but off best levels amid crude retreat, Chinese trade and looming Trump announcement on Iran
  • Reports yesterday stated EU powers could be making attempts to convince Trump to stick with the deal. Later reports suggested Trump is said to be leaning towards dropping the Iran agreement and re-imposing sanctions
  • Looking ahead, highlights include German trade, Riksbank minutes, APIs, Fed’s Powell, President Trump (Iranian announcement) and a 3yr note auction

HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE WEEKEND/MONDAY FOR UK PARTICIPANTS

League leader Salvini and 5 Stars Di Maio agreed that if there is no agreement for a political government, elections should be held in 8th July. Furthermore, Salvini said that after meeting with President Mattarella he is willing to form a government as Prime Minister (Newswires)

Senior Iranian Oil Ministry Official says said Iran sanctions cannot stop oil industry advancement and that the nuclear deal can stay alive if Iran sells crude. Saudi Energy minister says they have to wait until the June OPEC meeting to decide what the target is (Newswires)

Iranian foreign minister said that Tehran's reaction if the US leave the nuclear deal will not be pleasant, and they will pay a heavy price. This is ahead of the decision to be made on May 12th by the US on the Iranian nuclear deal, which the US is slated to be leaving. (Newswires)

Riksbank's Jochnik said they follow the SEK closely but the inflation target is key; says Riksbank has discussed hiking rates between 0.1% and 0.25% when the time comes to begin lifting rates. (Newswires)

Warren Buffett said "it wouldn't take me a nanosecond" in the current environment to S&P500 over 10- or 30-year US treasuries. (CNBC)

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded mostly positive following a similar performance on Wall St where all 3 majors closed in the green but off best levels after a late retreat in crude, while mixed Chinese trade data and a looming Trump announcement on the Iran agreement has also kept upside in the region contained. ASX 200 (+0.2%) is positive with gains led by strength in the largest weighted financials sector and amid some optimism ahead of the federal budget announcement which is expected to include tax cuts for low and middle-income earners, as well as billions for infrastructure spending. Elsewhere, Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) shrugged off a firmer currency and conformed to the overall risk appetite, while Hang Seng (+1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.9%) outperformed with healthcare and financials front running the gains despite further liquidity inaction and another consecutive net neutral position by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lacklustre as focus centred on riskier assets, while the 10yr JGB auction also failed to impact prices with the results somewhat inconclusive in which the b/c printed higher than previous and accepted prices declined.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires)
PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3674 (Prev. 6.3584)

Chinese Trade Balance (CNY)(Apr) 182.8B vs. Exp. 189.15B (Prev. -29.8B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (CNY)(Apr) 3.7% vs. Exp. 4.0% (Prev. -9.8%)
Chinese Imports (CNY)(Apr) 11.6% vs. Exp. 10.4% (Prev. 5.9%)

Chinese Trade Balance (USD)(Apr) 28.78B vs. Exp. 27.80B (Prev. -4.98B). (Newswires)
Chinese Exports (USD)(Apr) Y/Y 12.9% vs. Exp. 8.0% (Prev. -2.7%)
Chinese Imports (USD)(Apr) Y/Y 21.5% vs. Exp. 16.0% (Prev. 14.4%)

UK/EU

UK PM May is reportedly facing renewed turmoil regarding Brexit options and is said to be under pressure from MPs across different parties to accept EEA membership or risk defeat in Commons. (Guardian) Furthermore, Dozens of Eurosceptic MPs in the UK's Conservative party are expected to express their frustration today regarding a lack of direction for the UK's future post-Brexit. (Telegraph)

ECB’s Praet (dovish, chief-economist) claims that overall an ample degree of monetary stimulus is still required. Praet added the negative surprise in inflation was mainly attributable to a decrease in services inflation reflecting the timing of Easter. (Newswires)

ECB's Smets (N/A) said ECB could take steps to phase out QE this summer. Smets added investors could be right in pushing back forecasts for when the ECB might start hiking rates for first time since the financial crisis (WSJ)

Italian President Mattarella said that the meetings on Monday showed there was no chance to form a government and a minority government would lead to new elections. Furthermore, Mattarella said he is worried about having an early election in summer and sees a new vote just after December, while he added that he sees possible market risks coming. (Newswires) Italy's League party said Italy must have a centre-right government or early elections and ruled out President Mattarella's suggestion of a neutral government until the end of the year. Furthermore, Five-Star Movement ruled out support for a neutral government and said elections must take place in July, while Berlusconi's Forza Italia is said to discuss the political situation with allies and is not worried of a vote but would rather have an election in autumn rather than in July

FX

In FX markets, the DXY initially traded choppy although has since rebounded off its lows which has resulted to a capitulation in EUR/USD and GBP/USD. Elsewhere, USD/JPY oscillated around 109.00 and NZD weakened on reduced inflation expectations, while AUD was pressured following disappointing Retail Sales data and after mixed Chinese trade data failed to support prices.

Australian Retail Sales (Mar) M/M 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.6%). (Newswires)
Australian Retail Sales (Q1) Q/Q 0.2% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.9%)

New Zealand Inflation Expectations (Q2) Q/Q 2.0% (Prev. 2.1%). (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures retreated back below the USD 70.00/bbl level following reports that European powers were close to a package deal to try and persuade Trump not to withdraw from the Iran deal. Furthermore, although there were reports that Trump is said to be inclined to dropping out of the Iran nuclear agreement when he announces his decision later today, it was also suggested that the prospect of some moderation by Trump cannot fully be dismissed. Elsewhere, gold prices were choppy and ultimately declined as the greenback recovered, while copper fared better than its peers on the positive risk appetite and outperformance in China.

 GEOPOLITICS

UK, France and Germany are close to a package deal to attempt to persuade US President Trump not to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal, according to a senior diplomat. (Channel 10/Twitter)

US President Trump is to announce decision on the Iran nuclear deal tomorrow at 1400ET/1900BST. Furthermore, there were later reports that US President Trump is said to be leaning towards dropping the Iran agreement and re-imposing sanctions according to diplomats familiar with discussions, although reports added it is unclear if he would moderate a move to scrap the Iran nuclear deal by permitting EU countries to proceed with economic ties with Iran without being penalized by US. (Newswires/NYT)

US

Treasuries were pretty much unchanged for the session with London away from market and in anticipation of the Thursday’s CPI release and ahead of the USD 73bln auctions this week where the Treasury will sell USD 31bln in 3yr, USD 25bln in 10yr and USD 17bln in 30yr. Amid thin volume, yields were only mildly higher on Monday with 5yr, 10yr and 30yr up by less than 1bps.

Fed's Barkin (voter) noted monetary policy is still pretty accommodative but declined to say how many rate hikes he sees for this year. (Newswires)

Fed’s Bostic (voter, dovish) appeared comfortable with ‘some degree’ of overshooting on inflation and reiterated his view for 2 more rate hikes in 2018. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (non-voter., neutral) said there is plenty of stimulus for the economy amid tight labour market and said that the yield curve reflects scepticism regarding medium-term outlook. Furthermore, Kaplan said that the base case remains at 3 hikes total for this year. (Newswires)

Senior White House official stated that President Trump will request USD 15bln in spending reductions from Congress which will be focused on money not being utilized.  Furthermore, the official stated that cuts will include USD 7bln from the Children's health insurance program and that another large recission package will be proposed later in the year. (Newswires)

content:

ASX 200 (+0.4%) is positive with gains led by strength in the largest weighted financials sector and amid some optimism ahead of the federal budget announcement which is expected to include tax cuts for low and middle-income earners, as well as billions for infrastructure spending.
